title: Czech Republic 2-3 Northern Ireland: Michael O'Neill's side win first away friendly in 13 YEARS
text:
Northern Ireland won a friendly international away from home for the first time in 13 years, holding on for victory over the Czech Republic three days after England's shock defeat in Prague.

It was a very different Czech line-up with coach Jaroslav Silhavy making a total of 10 changes at the Generali Arena, and Michael O'Neill's side took full advantage of a ragged first-half performance from the home side.

Middlesbrough's Paddy McNair scored twice as he stole in to reach Liam Boyce's cross and guide a shot past Jiri Pavlenka before racing clear onto Steven Davis' throughball to round the Czech keeper and make it 3-0 before half-time.

Northern Ireland won their first away friendly international game in 13 years on Monday night

Paddy McNair scored twice to give Michael O'Neill's side a commanding 3-0 first half lead

The former Manchester United player broke free and rounded the keeper to score the third

Jonny Evans got Northern Ireland's other goal, converting after a goalmouth scramble that followed McNair's corner.

The Czechs made changes at the interval and it altered the flow of the game as they struck twice in as many minutes midway through the second half.

Two of the substitutes - Zdenek Ondrasek and Vladimar Darida - combined for the latter to beat Michael McGovern, and then Alex Kral scored an excellent solo goal.

They had the ball in the net again in injury-time but it was ruled out for a foul on McGovern by Ondrasek, the hero against England on Friday.
description: CHRIS WHEELER IN PRAGUE: Jonny Evans got Northern Ireland's other goal, converting after a goalmouth scramble that followed McNair's corner after McNair scored two first half goals.
authors: Chris Wheeler For The Daily Mail
